title: Ezekiel Chapter 18 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 18 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 18 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 18.

questions.question: What proverb is mentioned in Ezekiel 18:2 that the people of Israel were using?
options: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
A wise man builds his house upon the rock
The lion shall lie down with the lamb
The meek shall inherit the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:2 specifically mentions this proverb used by the people of Israel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18:4, whose souls belong to the Lord GOD?
options: The soul of the father and the son
Only the soul of the father
Only the soul of the son
The souls of the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The soul of the father and the son
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:4 states that all souls belong to God, including both father and son.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18:5, what must a man do to be considered just?
options: Do that which is lawful and right
Offer sacrifices daily
Fast every week
Build altars on the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Do that which is lawful and right
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:5 says that a just man is one who does what is lawful and right.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed in Ezekiel 18:6 as something a just man avoids?
options: Eating upon the mountains
Lifting up his eyes to idols
Defiling his neighbour's wife
Ignoring the poor and needy
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring the poor and needy
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:6 lists eating on mountains, idolatry, and defiling a neighbour's wife but does not mention ignoring the poor here; that is addressed later.

questions.question: What act of kindness is mentioned in Ezekiel 18:7 as part of just behavior?
options: Giving bread to the hungry
Building a temple
Offering sacrifices
Planting vineyards
questions.correctAnswer: Giving bread to the hungry
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:7 mentions giving bread to the hungry as an example of just conduct.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18:8, what financial practice does a just man avoid?
options: Giving out money on usury
Paying taxes
Donating to the temple
Trading goods
questions.correctAnswer: Giving out money on usury
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:8 states that a just man does not give money on usury nor take increase.

questions.question: What will happen to the soul that sinneth, according to Ezekiel 18:4 and 18:20?
options: It shall die
It shall be forgiven automatically
It shall be rewarded
It shall live forever
questions.correctAnswer: It shall die
questions.explanation: Both Ezekiel 18:4 and 18:20 clearly state that the soul that sinneth shall die.

questions.question: Who bears the iniquity of the father according to Ezekiel 18:20?
options: The father only
The son only
The son and the father equally
Neither the son nor the father
questions.correctAnswer: Neither the son nor the father
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 teaches that the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, nor the father bear the iniquity of the son.

questions.question: If a wicked man turns from all his sins and does what is lawful and right, what will happen to him according to Ezekiel 18:21?
options: He shall surely live
He shall be punished
He shall be ignored
He shall be exiled
questions.correctAnswer: He shall surely live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:21 promises that a wicked man who repents and obeys God's statutes shall surely live.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18:23, what does the Lord GOD prefer over the death of the wicked?
options: That he should return from his ways and live
That he should be forgotten
That he should be punished
That he should be exiled
questions.correctAnswer: That he should return from his ways and live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:23 states God’s desire that the wicked turn from sin and live rather than die.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 18:9 says that a just man who walks in God's statutes shall surely live.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:9 confirms that a just man who obeys God's laws shall live.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 18:26 states that a righteous man who turns away from righteousness and dies in sin will live.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:26 says that when a righteous man turns to sin and dies in it, he shall die for his iniquity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 18:32, God has pleasure in the death of the wicked.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:32 states God has no pleasure in the death of anyone who dies but desires that they turn and live.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Ezekiel 18:31: 'Cast away from you all your ________, and make you a new heart and a new spirit.'
options: transgressions
sins
idols
falsehoods
questions.correctAnswer: transgressions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:31 specifically says to cast away all transgressions and make a new heart and spirit.

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Ezekiel 18:19: 'When the son hath done that which is lawful and right, and hath kept all my statutes, and hath done them, he shall surely ______.'
options: live
die
be punished
be forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:19 states that the son who obeys God shall surely live.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 18 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 18 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with guilt over their parents' sins. Based on Ezekiel 18, what biblical truth would you share about personal responsibility?
options: Each person is accountable for their own sin.
Children always bear the consequences of their parents' sins.
God punishes families collectively without distinction.
Righteousness or wickedness is inherited automatically.
questions.correctAnswer: Each person is accountable for their own sin.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 teaches that 'the soul that sinneth, it shall die' and that 'the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, neither shall the father bear the iniquity of the son'. This affirms personal responsibility rather than inherited guilt (verses 4, 19, 20).

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 instruct believers to respond when they realize they have erred and sinned?
options: They should repent, turn from their sins, and live.
They should accept their fate and continue as before.
They must perform sacrifices to atone for their sins.
They should blame others for their shortcomings.
questions.correctAnswer: They should repent, turn from their sins, and live.
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes repentance and turning away from sin as the path to life (Ezekiel 18:21, 27, 28, 30, 32). God desires that the wicked turn and live rather than die in sin.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, what characterizes a righteous person in their daily conduct?
options: Doing what is lawful and right, not oppressing others, and helping the needy.
Keeping religious rituals without concern for others.
Avoiding all social interactions to prevent sin.
Seeking wealth and power regardless of means.
questions.correctAnswer: Doing what is lawful and right, not oppressing others, and helping the needy.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-9 describe a righteous person as one who acts justly, restores pledges, gives to the hungry, covers the naked, does not oppress, and walks in God's statutes.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand God's fairness in judgment. What does Ezekiel 18 say about God's ways compared to human ways?
options: God's ways are equal, but human ways are unequal.
God is unfair and partial in His judgments.
God judges only a few people.
God ignores sins if people appear religious.
questions.correctAnswer: God's ways are equal, but human ways are unequal.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:25 and 29 emphasize that God's way is equal and just, while human ways are often unequal and unjust, challenging the people's complaints.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 illustrate the importance of integrity in work and business?
options: By condemning usury, oppression, and failure to restore pledges.
By encouraging accumulation of wealth by any means.
By focusing only on religious observances.
By ignoring economic practices as irrelevant to righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: By condemning usury, oppression, and failure to restore pledges.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 and 12-13 condemn oppression, taking usury, not restoring pledges, and violence as sins contrary to God's statutes.

questions.question: What practical lesson about forgiveness and new beginnings does Ezekiel 18 teach?
options: God will not remember past sins if one truly repents and lives righteously.
Past sins always prevent a person from being accepted by God.
Forgiveness is only for certain people.
One must pay with suffering to erase sins.
questions.correctAnswer: God will not remember past sins if one truly repents and lives righteously.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:22 states that all transgressions will not be mentioned to the repentant, highlighting God's readiness to forgive those who live righteously.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 encourage believers to deal with temptation and sin?
options: By turning away from sinful acts and embracing God's statutes.
By ignoring sin and hoping it will go away.
By blaming others for their own sins.
By accepting that sin is unavoidable and unchangeable.
questions.correctAnswer: By turning away from sinful acts and embracing God's statutes.
questions.explanation: The chapter stresses the importance of turning from all transgressions and following God's statutes to live (Ezekiel 18:30-31).

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 18, the son will always suffer for the sins of his father.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 clearly states that the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father; each person is responsible for their own sin.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 18 teaches that God takes no pleasure in the death of the wicked but desires their repentance and life.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:23 and 32 express God's desire that the wicked turn from their ways and live, showing His compassion.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness after being wronged. Based on Ezekiel 18, what attitude should they cultivate towards others?
options: Forgiveness and love, helping those in need without oppression.
Retaliation to maintain justice.
Indifference to others' needs.
Holding grudges as a way to protect oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: Forgiveness and love, helping those in need without oppression.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 emphasize giving bread to the hungry, covering the naked, and not oppressing others, reflecting a loving and forgiving heart.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 guide believers in parenting with biblical wisdom?
options: Each child is judged by their own actions, so teaching righteousness is vital.
Children will inherit their parents' sins regardless of their own choices.
Parents are solely responsible for their children's fate.
Raising children religiously guarantees their righteousness.
questions.correctAnswer: Each child is judged by their own actions, so teaching righteousness is vital.
questions.explanation: Verses 14-17 show a son who sees his father's sins but chooses righteousness and lives, underscoring personal choice and the importance of teaching.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 18:31, God calls us to cast away all our __________ and make a new heart and spirit.
options: sins
transgressions
faults
errors
questions.correctAnswer: transgressions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:31 specifically commands to cast away all transgressions and create a new heart and spirit as part of repentance.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 18 teach about the effect of turning away from righteousness and doing evil?
options: The person shall die for their iniquity despite past righteousness.
Past righteousness will always save the person.
God will overlook the evil if done once.
The person will be rewarded for previous good deeds.
questions.correctAnswer: The person shall die for their iniquity despite past righteousness.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:24 and 26 explain that if a righteous person turns to sin, they shall die for their iniquity, and their past righteousness will not be counted.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 encourage believers to demonstrate humility and contentment in their lives?
options: By walking in God's statutes, dealing truly, and not seeking unjust gain.
By striving to be seen as religiously superior.
By accumulating wealth through any means.
By withdrawing from community and fellowship.
questions.correctAnswer: By walking in God's statutes, dealing truly, and not seeking unjust gain.
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 9 highlight humility and integrity through honest dealings and obedience to God's laws.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship and generosity is taught in Ezekiel 18?
options: Giving bread to the hungry and clothing the naked is part of righteous living.
One should keep all possessions for oneself.
Generosity is optional and unrelated to righteousness.
Only priests are responsible for caring for the needy.
questions.correctAnswer: Giving bread to the hungry and clothing the naked is part of righteous living.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:7 and 16 show that helping the hungry and naked is integral to justice and righteousness before God.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 18 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 18.

questions.question: What proverb does God command the Israelites to no longer use according to Ezekiel 18?
options: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
A house divided against itself cannot stand
Man shall not live by bread alone
The lion shall lie down with the lamb
questions.correctAnswer: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:2-3 addresses this proverb directly, with God stating that it shall no longer be used in Israel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, who does the soul belong to?
options: The soul that sinneth, it shall die
The soul belongs to the father only
The soul belongs to the son only
The soul belongs to the community
questions.correctAnswer: The soul that sinneth, it shall die
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:4 emphasizes that each soul is God's and the soul that sins will die, indicating individual responsibility.

questions.question: Which of the following actions is NOT listed as part of the just man's conduct in Ezekiel 18?
options: Oppressing the poor
Restoring the debtor his pledge
Giving bread to the hungry
Not defiling his neighbour's wife
questions.correctAnswer: Oppressing the poor
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:7 explicitly states the just man does not oppress anyone but restores pledges and helps the needy.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 18 say about a man who commits all abominations like eating on the mountains and defiling his neighbour's wife?
options: He shall surely die; his blood shall be upon him
He will be forgiven if he repents
He will inherit the kingdom of God
He shall live with his father
questions.correctAnswer: He shall surely die; his blood shall be upon him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:13 states that such a man shall not live because he has done abominations, emphasizing personal accountability.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'The soul that sinneth, it shall ___. The son shall not bear the iniquity of the father.'
options: live
die
inherit
prosper
questions.correctAnswer: die
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 clearly states the principle that the soul that sins shall die and the son will not bear the father's iniquity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 18, the sins of the fathers will always be visited upon their children.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 clarifies that the son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, highlighting individual responsibility.

questions.question: Which theme present in Ezekiel 18 is echoed later in the New Testament's teaching on repentance and forgiveness?
options: Individual responsibility and repentance
Collective punishment
Predestination
Sacrificial atonement
questions.correctAnswer: Individual responsibility and repentance
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:21-22 emphasizes turning from sin and doing right to live, paralleling New Testament teachings such as those in Acts 3:19.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 18 when contrasting the righteous and the wicked and their outcomes?
options: Chiasm
Allegory
Parable
Foreshadowing
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18 uses a chiastic structure contrasting righteous and wicked behavior and their consequences, emphasizing symmetry in divine justice.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, what does God desire for the wicked rather than their death?
options: That they should return from their ways and live
That they should be punished forever
That they should be ignored
That they should inherit the land
questions.correctAnswer: That they should return from their ways and live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:23 states God's desire for the wicked to repent and live, showing His mercy and desire for restoration.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 18 address the concept of intergenerational punishment common in ancient Near Eastern cultures?
options: Rejects it by affirming individual accountability
Supports it fully without exception
Ignores it completely
Suggests punishment only for firstborn sons
questions.correctAnswer: Rejects it by affirming individual accountability
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 refutes the traditional belief that children suffer for their parents’ sins, emphasizing personal guilt or innocence.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term often translated as 'soul' (nephesh) is used in Ezekiel 18 to emphasize personal responsibility?
options: Nephesh
Ruach
Neshamah
Chayah
questions.correctAnswer: Nephesh
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'nephesh' (soul) in Ezekiel 18:4 highlights the personal nature of life and accountability to God.

questions.question: What cultural practice mentioned in Ezekiel 18:6 is condemned as defiling by the prophet?
options: Coming near to a menstruous woman
Eating unclean animals
Worshiping at high places
Engaging in ritual baths
questions.correctAnswer: Coming near to a menstruous woman
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:6 condemns approaching a menstruous woman, reflecting Israelite purity laws of the ancient Near East.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 18 teaches that a righteous man who turns away from righteousness will still be remembered for his good deeds and live.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:24 states that if a righteous man turns to iniquity, his past righteousness will not be remembered and he shall die.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 18, what is the consequence for one who 'executeth true judgment between man and man' and 'walketh in my statutes'?
options: He shall surely live
He shall be exiled
He shall be ignored
He shall be cursed
questions.correctAnswer: He shall surely live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:9 promises that a just man who obeys God's statutes will live, underscoring divine justice and reward.

questions.question: What is the authorial intent behind Ezekiel 18 addressing the proverb about sour grapes in the context of Israel's exile?
options: To overturn the belief that descendants suffer for ancestors' sins
To emphasize collective punishment for sins
To promote idolatry as acceptable
To justify the exile as unchangeable fate
questions.correctAnswer: To overturn the belief that descendants suffer for ancestors' sins
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18 was written during the Babylonian exile to correct Israel’s misunderstanding of communal guilt and to encourage personal repentance.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 18 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 18 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What proverb does God forbid the people of Israel from using any longer according to Ezekiel 18?
options: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
A house divided against itself cannot stand
The lion shall lie down with the lamb
Man shall not live by bread alone
questions.correctAnswer: The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:2-3 forbids the use of the proverb that the sins of the fathers cause suffering in the children, emphasizing individual responsibility for sin. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 24:16, Jeremiah 31:29-30, Galatians 6:5, and 2 Corinthians 5:10 which affirm personal accountability.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, who does the soul belong to and what is the consequence of sin?
options: The soul belongs to God; the soul that sinneth shall die
The soul belongs to the family; the sins of the father affect the son
The soul belongs to the community; judgment is communal
The soul belongs to the individual; sin has no consequence
questions.correctAnswer: The soul belongs to God; the soul that sinneth shall die
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:4 declares that all souls belong to God and that the soul which sins shall die, affirming divine sovereignty and individual responsibility. This aligns with Romans 14:12, Ezekiel 33:20, Hebrews 9:27, and James 1:15.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed among the righteous acts of a just man in Ezekiel 18?
options: Eating upon the mountains
Restoring the debtor his pledge
Giving bread to the hungry
Not oppressing anyone
questions.correctAnswer: Eating upon the mountains
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:6-7 describes righteous behavior including restoring pledges, feeding the hungry, and not oppressing others. Eating upon the mountains is associated with idolatry and disobedience, thus not a righteous act. See also Leviticus 17:7, Deuteronomy 12:13-14, Isaiah 1:17, and Matthew 25:35-40.

questions.question: What is the divine verdict for a son who commits robbery, bloodshed, and other abominations as described in Ezekiel 18?
options: He shall surely die; his blood shall be upon him
He shall live because of his father's righteousness
He shall be forgiven without repentance
He shall bear the iniquity of his father
questions.correctAnswer: He shall surely die; his blood shall be upon him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:10-13 states that a son who commits such sins shall die for his own iniquity. This stresses individual accountability consistent with Numbers 35:33, Deuteronomy 19:21, Romans 6:23, and Ezekiel 33:8.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, what happens if a son sees his father's sins but does not follow them and instead lives righteously?
options: He shall not die for the iniquity of his father; he shall surely live
He will be punished for his father's sins
He will inherit his father's guilt
He will be rejected by God
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not die for the iniquity of his father; he shall surely live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:14-17 teaches that a son who refuses to follow his father's sins and lives righteously will live and not bear his father's iniquity. This aligns with Ezekiel 33:12-16, Jeremiah 31:29-30, Galatians 6:7, and 2 Corinthians 5:10.

questions.question: What is the theological principle stated in Ezekiel 18:20 regarding sin and personal responsibility?
options: The soul that sinneth shall die; the son shall not bear the father's iniquity
The sins of the father are visited upon the son
The community bears the guilt of individual sin
Righteousness and wickedness are inherited traits
questions.correctAnswer: The soul that sinneth shall die; the son shall not bear the father's iniquity
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:20 clearly states individual responsibility for sin, rejecting collective guilt. This principle is confirmed in Deuteronomy 24:16, Jeremiah 31:29, Romans 2:6, and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 18 say about the possibility of the wicked turning from their sins?
options: If the wicked turn from all their sins and keep God's statutes, they shall surely live
The wicked are doomed regardless of repentance
Only the righteous can be saved
Repentance is unnecessary for salvation
questions.correctAnswer: If the wicked turn from all their sins and keep God's statutes, they shall surely live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:21-22 teaches that the wicked who repent and obey God will live, showing God's mercy and justice. This is consistent with 2 Chronicles 7:14, Isaiah 55:7, Acts 3:19, and 1 John 1:9.

questions.question: How does God express His attitude toward the death of the wicked in Ezekiel 18?
options: God has no pleasure in the death of the wicked but desires their repentance and life
God delights in punishing the wicked
God is indifferent to the fate of sinners
God immediately condemns sinners without warning
questions.correctAnswer: God has no pleasure in the death of the wicked but desires their repentance and life
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:23 and 32 emphasize God's desire for the wicked to repent and live rather than die, revealing His merciful nature. Similar sentiments appear in Ezekiel 33:11, 2 Peter 3:9, John 3:16, and Romans 2:4.

questions.question: What happens to the righteousness of a man who turns away from it and commits iniquity according to Ezekiel 18?
options: His past righteousness will not be remembered; he will die for his sin
His righteousness will still save him
He will be punished but eventually forgiven without repentance
His righteousness will outweigh his sins
questions.correctAnswer: His past righteousness will not be remembered; he will die for his sin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:24 teaches that turning from righteousness to sin causes loss of the benefit of prior righteousness and results in death for sin, consistent with Hebrews 10:26-27, Galatians 5:4, 2 Peter 2:20-22, and Matthew 7:21-23.

questions.question: What objection from the house of Israel does God address repeatedly in Ezekiel 18, and how does He respond?
options: They say God's way is not equal; God responds that His way is indeed equal and their ways are unequal
They claim God is unjust for punishing the righteous; God agrees
They say God only punishes the wicked; God says He punishes all
They believe repentance is unnecessary; God affirms this
questions.correctAnswer: They say God's way is not equal; God responds that His way is indeed equal and their ways are unequal
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:25, 29 addresses the complaint that God's judgments are unfair, with God affirming His perfect justice and pointing out Israel's unequal ways. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 89:14, Romans 3:4, and James 2:1.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 18, what is required of the house of Israel to avoid ruin from iniquity?
options: Repent and turn from all transgressions
Offer more sacrifices
Build a temple
Follow the traditions of the elders
questions.correctAnswer: Repent and turn from all transgressions
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:30 commands Israel to repent and turn away from their sins to avoid destruction. This call to repentance is echoed in Joel 2:12-13, Isaiah 55:6-7, Acts 17:30, and 2 Chronicles 7:14.

questions.question: What transformation does God call the people of Israel to make in Ezekiel 18:31?
options: Make a new heart and a new spirit
Increase their ritual offerings
Build altars to God
Perform acts of charity only
questions.correctAnswer: Make a new heart and a new spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:31 urges Israel to repent by creating a new heart and spirit, indicating inner renewal. This theme is consistent with Jeremiah 31:33, Ezekiel 36:26, Romans 12:2, and 2 Corinthians 5:17.

questions.question: What final exhortation does God give to Israel in Ezekiel 18:32?
options: Turn yourselves and live
Prepare for judgment without hope
Trust in your own righteousness
Ignore the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Turn yourselves and live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:32 concludes with a call to repentance and life, emphasizing God's desire for salvation rather than death. This is consistent with John 5:40, Acts 2:38, 1 Timothy 2:4, and Ezekiel 33:11.

questions.question: Which of the following actions is described as evidence of walking in God's statutes in Ezekiel 18?
options: Executing true judgment between man and man
Building high places on mountains
Lifting up eyes to idols
Taking usury and increase
questions.correctAnswer: Executing true judgment between man and man
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:8-9 highlights executing true judgment as part of obedience to God's statutes. This principle aligns with Psalm 82:3-4, Isaiah 1:17, Micah 6:8, and James 2:1-8.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 18 say about those who give bread to the hungry and cover the naked with a garment?
options: They are considered just and shall surely live
They are still guilty of sin and will die
These acts are irrelevant to righteousness
They will inherit their father's sins
questions.correctAnswer: They are considered just and shall surely live
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 18:7,16 teaches that acts of charity like feeding the hungry and clothing the naked demonstrate righteousness that leads to life. This aligns with Proverbs 19:17, Isaiah 58:7, Matthew 25:35-40, and James 1:27.
